And at the end of the day you’ll find yourself getting much more tired. A great approach is, if you’re doing mental work, try to instead do some kind of movement during your breaks, something where your brain can relax and your mind can do some wandering. All of this is very important because in the past we’ve always thought that learning only took place when we were focusing our attention on something. But we now understand that an important part of learning takes place when we’re not focusing on something. In fact, to truly understand something we often need periods where we’ve switched our attention off the material we’re trying to understand, because that’s the time when we consolidate and make sense of the material. We’re not consciously aware of this process, which is why we often don’t realize how important this consolidation process is for learning, memory, and long-term creativity. We’ve heard from tens of thousands of learners in Learning How to Learn about how much they loved the Pomodoro Technique. People often ask, well, why 25 minutes? 我们都没有完全听话的心智，谢天谢地，这意味着分心的想法是不可避免的。当你在进行番茄工作法时，不要试图将这些想法推开或告诉自己不要去想它们。相反，你只需承认这些分心的想法，然后在将注意力重新集中到你正在专注的任务上时，让它们悄然过去。

我们提到过番茄工作法的前三个组成部分，但实际上还有第四个组成部分。一旦你完成了一个番茄时间，就是奖励时间。你可以暂时将注意力转向任何你想做的事情。你可以听一首喜欢的歌，浏览你喜欢的社交媒体，观看一段有趣的舞蹈视频，自己跳一段有趣的舞，或者和朋友在线聊天。你也可以做一些活动，比如整理房间的一部分，走到厨房拿点咖啡或茶。整个理念是将注意力从刚刚专注的任务中移开。事实上，你想给刚刚使用的大脑部分一些休息时间。这意味着奖励不应该涉及类似类型的任务。例如，如果你在写报告，那么就不应该去Twitter或Facebook继续写，即使主题不同。这就像是在举重的间歇中，转而去抬书箱，依然是在进行重体力劳动，这意味着你并没有得到真正的休息。最终，你会发现自己变得更加疲惫。

一个很好的方法是，如果你在进行脑力工作，试着在休息时进行一些活动，让大脑放松，让思维自由游荡。这一切都非常重要，因为过去我们一直认为学习只发生在我们将注意力集中在某件事上时。但我们现在明白，学习的重要部分实际上是在我们不专注于某事的时候发生的。为了真正理解某个概念，我们通常需要有一些时间，将注意力从我们试图理解的材料上移开，因为那是巩固和理解材料的时刻。

我们对此过程并不十分意识到，这也是为什么我们往往没有意识到巩固过程对学习、记忆和长期创造力的重要性。我们在《学习如何学习》中听到了成千上万学习者对番茄工作法的喜爱。人们常常问，为什么选择25分钟？

Remember that pain in the brain that pops up when we think about something we really didn’t want to do? It seems that when we decide to go ahead and work on that task despite the pain, that pain often lasts about 20 minutes. In other words, doing a pomodoro helps you just get past the pain and into the flow of the work. I do have to admit, if I really get going and into the flow, I don’t necessarily make myself stop at the end of a pomodoro session. I just keep going as long as it feels good, which, of course, is fine too. People often also wonder about how long the break should be between pomodoros. Well, this depends on you, and what you’ve got going on. Maybe it’s final examination time, or you’ve got a massively important presentation to prepare for. In this case, you may only want to have maybe 3 to 5 minutes between pomodoros. But if you’re not in such a crunch time, perhaps you can take 10 or 20 minutes. Some people set a pomodoro timer as a sort of, worst case I only have to do 25 minutes, sort of motivator. The pomodoro helps them to get started, but if they get into the flow, and are liking what they’re doing, they won’t necessarily quit at the end of the 25 minutes. 记住，当我们想到一些我们不想做的事情时，大脑中出现的那种痛苦吗？似乎当我们决定尽管感到痛苦也要继续进行那个任务时，这种痛苦通常持续约20分钟。换句话说，进行一个番茄时间帮助你克服这种痛苦，进入工作的流畅状态。 我确实得承认，如果我真的进入状态，流畅地工作，我并不一定会在番茄时间结束时强迫自己停止。我会继续进行，只要感觉良好，这当然也没问题。人们也常常想知道，番茄工作法之间的休息时间应该多长。这取决于你自己的情况，以及你正在进行的工作。也许这是期末考试时期，或者你正在准备一场非常重要的演讲。在这种情况下，你可能只想在番茄工作法之间休息3到5分钟。 但如果你并不是处于紧迫状态，也许可以休息10到20分钟。有些人会将番茄计时器设置为一种“最坏情况下我只需要做25分钟”的激励。番茄工作法帮助他们开始工作，但如果他们进入状态并喜欢自己正在做的事情，他们不一定会在25分钟结束时停止。

You might also ask, how do I get myself restarted doing a pomodoro once I’ve taken a break? This also depends a lot on you. Everyone’s motivated differently. One motivator is to download an app onto your phone that gives you badges for each pomodoro you finish. People often enjoy collecting these badges each day, and you can set a goal for yourself, perhaps two pomodoros for work related to one topic, maybe three related to another, and so forth. There are also other motivators you can use. We’ll talk about them in the next video. The Pomodoro Technique is, in reality, a powerful and actually enjoyable type of meditation through work. Smart learners make great use of this. 你可能还会问，在休息后我该如何重新开始进行番茄工作法？这在很大程度上取决于你自己。每个人的动机不同。一个激励方法是下载一个应用程序到你的手机上，这个应用可以为你完成的每个番茄时间颁发徽章。人们通常喜欢每天收集这些徽章，你可以给自己设定一个目标，比如在某个主题上完成两个番茄时间，在另一个主题上完成三个，依此类推。

你还可以使用其他激励方法。我们将在下一个视频中讨论这些。实际上，番茄工作法是一种通过工作进行的强大而愉快的冥想形式。聪明的学习者会充分利用这一点。

2-5 Getting Past Procrastination

The Pomodoro Technique is a powerful tool to help guard against procrastination. But it can also help to take a bit of a step back when you catch yourself procrastinating to look at the bigger picture. Researcher Piers Steel has analyzed many of the different motivators and demotivators of procrastination, which he’s written about in his book, The Procrastination Equation. Basically, Steel has found that you get yourself motivated to perform a task. Say to, write a report for work or to prepare for an examination at the university when you expect a reward or success. So you want to do what you can to increase the expectancy of success and the certainty of being rewarded. You also get motivated when you value the task and the task is pleasant. So you want to do what you can to increase the value and the pleasantness of the task. But on the other hand, you get unmotivated to perform a task when you get distracted or lose focus when you’re affected by impulsiveness. So you want to do what you can to remove distractions and maintain your focus. Steel’s ideas were combined into a very helpful flow chart by program management analyst Alex Vermeer. Basically, to get a handle on procrastination, you want to notice when your procrastination. Be specific about what you’re avoiding. And to get motivated you’ll want to focus on one of the three areas we just mentioned to increase expectancy, to increase value, or to decrease impulsiveness. So, how would you, for example, increase value? Well, one way is to find a greater meaning in what you’re working on. And you do that, for example, by setting and reviewing your major life’s goals. And asking yourself how they connect with what you’re doing. You might also find a way to get into the flow with the material. Make sure that what you’re doing is not to tough, or too easy. And sometimes it helps to create a sense of competition. You can compete against yourself, against your colleagues or you can just turn what you’re doing into a game in whatever way you’d like. 番茄工作法是一种强有力的工具，可以帮助抵御拖延。但当你发现自己在拖延时，稍微后退一步，看看更大的图景也是有帮助的。研究者皮尔斯·斯蒂尔分析了许多与拖延相关的动机和非动机因素，并在他的书《拖延方程式》中进行了详细阐述。

基本上，斯蒂尔发现，想要激励自己完成某个任务，比如写工作报告或准备大学考试，你需要期待某种奖励或成功。因此，你要尽可能提高成功的期望和获得奖励的确定性。同时，当你重视某个任务并觉得这个任务愉快时，也会激励你去做。因此，你要尽可能提高任务的价值和愉悦感。

另一方面，当你分心或失去专注，被冲动影响时，你会对完成某个任务缺乏动机。因此，你需要尽量消除干扰，保持专注。斯蒂尔的观点被程序管理分析师亚历克斯·范梅尔整理成了一个非常有用的流程图。基本上，要掌握拖延，你需要注意到何时开始拖延。具体明确你在回避什么。要激励自己，你需要专注于我们刚提到的三个领域之一：提高期望、提高价值或减少冲动。

那么，如何增加价值呢？一种方法是在你所做的事情中找到更大的意义。例如，通过设定和回顾你的人生主要目标，问问自己这些目标与自己正在做的事情有何联系。你也可以找到一种方法，让自己与材料融为一体。确保你正在做的事情既不太难，也不太简单。有时，创造竞争感也有助于提升动力。你可以与自己竞争，或与同事竞争，或者以你喜欢的任何方式把你正在做的事情变成一个游戏。

There’s a lot more to Vermeer’s chart of course. It’s important to keep energized, maybe by moving around a little, splashing some cold water in your face, putting on a little low-key music. And again, it’s also useful to create a reward for yourself. More generally, do what you can to keep your brain healthy. Add accountability, and find passion in what you’re working on. Now, to increase your sense of expectancy. Remember that if you don’t do anything, it guarantees failure. But this means you should pat yourself on the back when you succeed. It’s also important to be inspired and to be sure to plan ahead as much as possible. Another helpful strategy is to log your procrastination habits, and check your mindset. Have you inadvertently told yourself you just don’t have the talent instead of telling yourself you can develop the talent? 当然，范梅尔的图表还有更多内容。保持精力充沛很重要，可以通过稍微活动一下、往脸上泼点冷水、放一些轻松的音乐来实现。同样，为自己创造一个奖励也是非常有用的。更普遍地说，要尽量保持大脑健康。增加责任感，并在你所从事的工作中找到热情。

现在，为了提高你的期望感，请记住，如果什么都不做，那就注定会失败。这意味着当你成功时，应该给自己一个鼓励。同时，保持灵感也很重要，尽量提前做好规划。另一个有用的策略是记录你的拖延习惯，并检查你的心态。你是否无意中告诉自己没有才能，而不是告诉自己可以发展才能呢？

You can also work to reduce your impulsivity. The key here is to set a realistic goal and break it down into tiny little doable pieces. When you’re working on one of those pieces, set a timer. If you can’t do a 25 minute Pomodoro, just start with 5 minutes. Eliminate temptations and distractions like your phone or social media. Set up helpful routines and habits. Use goal reminders and make your goals visible, perhaps by putting them on your mirror so you can see them every morning. Stop trying to suppress distracting thoughts that pop up, instead acknowledge them and let them go right on by. And of course, keep track of your progress so you can feel good about your accomplishments. 你还可以努力减少冲动性。关键在于设定一个现实的目标，并将其拆分成小而可行的部分。当你专注于其中一个小部分时，设定一个计时器。如果你无法做到25分钟的番茄时间，可以从5分钟开始。消除诱惑和干扰，比如手机或社交媒体。建立有益的日常习惯和例行程序。使用目标提醒，让你的目标可见，例如把它们贴在镜子上，这样你每天早上都能看到。

停止试图压制那些突然出现的分心想法，而是承认它们并让它们悄然过去。最后，当然要跟踪你的进展，以便让你为自己的成就感到良好。

There’s one more thing with relation to procrastination. When you’re learning something, especially if it’s new and difficult, it’s not a good idea to procrastinate. Although you can sometimes really focus under the stress of impending deadline. That stress can also be uncomfortable and counterproductive, making it harder to learn something difficult. More than that, it takes time to grow the new neural synapses that form the foundation of any learning. This is why, as we’ve noted before, it’s important to space out your learning, doing a little every day, rather than trying to cram it all in on one short deadline. Your brain can only grow so many new synaptic connections in a day. And you also need many days of learning, and accompanying nights of good sleep, in order to effectively consolidate the material you’ve been learning. If you try to cram your learning, you’re laying a poor foundation. When the learning’s easy, like at the beginning of a course you’re taking, it can seem okay to procrastinate and cram. But gradually, as the course goes on, your weak foundation will start showing itself. You’ll start to think you just don’t have a knack for understanding the material when it isn’t that at all. You actually just haven’t put the time in to properly understanding and learning it. Sometimes, however, procrastination can be productive. This often relates to tasks where you’re synthesizing information. For example, when I was writing the book, Mindshift in preparation for doing this MOOC, I was doing a lot of travel around the world, meeting learners and talking with researchers. If I’d started writing too early, I wouldn’t have given myself the time I needed to properly gather enough information. I had to give myself time to make sure I collected enough of the right data before I started drawing conclusions. Believe it or not, some learner’s biggest challenge is that they want to dive right into writing a report or solving a problem without doing proper preparation. So this kind of, productive procrastination, where you’re gathering your knowledge base, is very important. In the end, if you feel overwhelmed by everything you’ve got to do, just focus on one thing, and keep track of what works best. Finally, remember to use the information in Alex’s full flow chart and Piers Steel useful book. Happy Mindshift. 关于拖延症，还有一件事需要注意。当你学习某样东西时，特别是新且困难的内容，拖延并不是一个好主意。尽管有时在即将到来的截止日期压力下你能够集中精力，但这种压力也可能让人感到不适并适得其反，使学习变得更加困难。更重要的是，形成新神经突触需要时间，而这些突触是学习的基础。这就是为什么我们之前提到，分散学习是重要的，每天做一点，而不是试图在短时间内突击学习。你的大脑每天能建立的新突触连接是有限的，而你还需要多天的学习和随之而来的良好睡眠，以有效巩固你所学的材料。如果你试图突击学习，你是在打下一个不牢固的基础。

当学习变得轻松时，比如在你参加课程的开始阶段，拖延和突击似乎是可以的。但随着课程的进展，你那薄弱的基础会开始显露出来。你可能会觉得自己对理解材料没有天赋，实际上并不是这样。你只是没有投入足够的时间去正确理解和学习它。

然而，有时拖延可以是有益的。这通常与你在综合信息的任务有关。例如，当我为这门慕课撰写《思维转变》一书时，我四处旅行，拜访学习者并与研究人员交流。如果我太早开始写作，就无法给自己足够的时间来收集足够的信息。我必须确保自己收集到足够正确的数据，然后再开始得出结论。

信不信由你，一些学习者最大的挑战是他们想在没有适当准备的情况下直接开始撰写报告或解决问题。因此，这种有生产性的拖延，即收集知识基础，是非常重要的。最后，如果你觉得要做的事情让你感到不堪重负，那就专注于一件事，并跟踪什么方法最有效。最后，记得利用亚历克斯的完整流程图和皮尔斯·斯蒂尔的有用书籍。祝你思维转变愉快！

2-6 The Value of Procedural Fluency and Deliberate Practice

So I have to tell you about a former student of mine. He came up, stuck out a red marked quiz that he just flunked and he said, I just don’t see how I could have done so poorly. I understood it when you taught it in class. Here’s the problem. In Western education, at least, we’ve gotten so wedded to the idea that conceptual understanding is the golden key to learning, that we’ve ignored the fact that practice and repetition is an equally vital aspect of learning. It’s that repeated banging away at it that ultimately can structure knowledge. Students themselves, including my former student, are fooled about how to learn effectively. In the past, for thousands of years the only way people thought learning happened was through memorization. People showed their learning mostly by just regurgitating what they’d memorized. Now, it’s not like this didn’t work at all. Otherwise, we’d never have the wonderful advances in the arts and sciences that we’ve seen in the last millennia. But of course, memorization isn’t everything in learning. 我必须告诉你一个我以前学生的故事。他走过来，递给我一份标记为红色的测验卷子，显然他刚刚挂科，他说：“我就是不明白为什么我会做得这么差。我在课堂上理解得很好。”问题在于，至少在西方教育中，我们过于执着于“概念理解是学习的金钥匙”这一理念，以至于忽视了实践和重复同样是学习中至关重要的方面。正是这种反复的练习，最终能够构建知识。

学生们，包括我的这位前学生，对如何有效学习有误解。在过去的几千年里，人们普遍认为学习只通过记忆实现。人们主要通过复述他们记住的内容来展示他们的学习成果。当然，这种方法并不是完全无效的。否则，我们不会在过去千年中看到如此辉煌的艺术和科学进步。但当然，记忆并不是学习的全部。

As a reaction to that extreme sort of learning equals memorization idea, in the last 100 years or so, a new approach has gradually arisen in Western ways of teaching. This approach says that conceptual understanding, not rote learning or memorization, is the key to learning. But in the West, at least, we’ve now gone off on to the other end of the extreme. We’ve gone so far overboard in emphasizing the unique importance of conceptual understanding that we’ve lost sight of the fact that some memorization in practice, especially deliberate practice that focuses on the hardest parts of the material, is also important in any kind of learning. In fact, practice and repetition, not to mention memorization, don’t just reinforce your understanding, they can actually lead to a deeper and richer understanding, as this paper shows. Poets often say, memorize the poem and you will understand it more deeply. But why should we in other disciplines let only the poets have all the fun? Memorizing an equation, for example, can help you understand that equation more deeply, especially if you’re trying to understand what’s going on with that equation as you’re memorizing it. Unfortunately, you’ll sometimes hear even advanced educators and educational psychologists in the West saying, it doesn’t matter, you can always look it up, in regards many forms of learning, especially in math and science. But that’s really not true. Would you know the French language, for example, if you had to go look words up every time you needed them? Would you know how to properly design an engine if you hadn’t spent time memorizing some of the equations, or at least working enough with them such that they flowed fluently in your mind? Would you really want your doctor to breeze through medical school without memorizing any of the hundreds of thousands of facts doctors are typically asked to memorize during their preparatory studies? Psychologist Anders Ericsson’s work has shown that all expertise develops through building strong, well practiced mental representations. That is, large libraries of solidly built neural chunks that can be easily drawn into working memory. The main point of this video is that practice, including some memorization, can help you to chunk key ideas and procedures, a vitally important part of learning. Remember how when you’re first trying to figure something out, the working memory of your prefrontal cortex is going a little crazy? Of course, once you’ve got that concept chunked, that is, understood and practiced, you basically have the equivalent of a nice, smooth ribbon that you can easily bring into working memory whenever you need to, leaving the other slots of working memory free to process other related chunks to hook them together to form more advanced thoughts. This is a key idea. 作为对“学习等于记忆”这一极端观点的反应，在过去100年左右，西方教育方法逐渐出现了一种新的理念。这种方法认为，概念理解，而非死记硬背或记忆，是学习的关键。然而，至少在西方，我们现在又走向了另一个极端。我们在强调概念理解的独特重要性方面过于偏激，以至于忽视了某些记忆和实践，尤其是专注于材料中最困难部分的刻意练习，在任何形式的学习中同样重要。

实际上，练习和重复，甚至记忆，不仅能加强你的理解，还能导致更深入、更丰富的理解，正如这篇论文所展示的。诗人们常常说：“记住这首诗，你会更深入地理解它。”但为什么在其他学科中，我们只能让诗人们享受这样的乐趣呢？例如，记忆一个方程式可以帮助你更深入地理解它，尤其是当你在记忆时努力理解这个方程式的含义时。

不幸的是，有时你会听到甚至是高级教育工作者和教育心理学家在西方说：“没关系，你可以随时查找”，这对于许多形式的学习，尤其是数学和科学而言。但这并不完全正确。例如，如果你每次需要法语单词时都必须查找，你还会懂法语吗？如果你没有花时间记忆一些方程式，或者至少足够熟练地运用它们，使它们在你脑海中流畅地出现，你真的能正确设计一台引擎吗？你会希望你的医生在医学院期间毫无记忆地轻松通过，忘记那些医生通常在准备学习过程中需要记住的成千上万的事实吗？

心理学家安德斯·艾瑞克森的研究表明，所有的专业技能都是通过构建强大且经过良好训练的心理表征而发展的。这就是构建大量坚实的神经块的过程，这些神经块可以轻松调入工作记忆中。这个视频的主要观点是，练习，包括一些记忆，可以帮助你将关键概念和程序进行分块，这是学习中至关重要的一部分。

记住，当你第一次试图搞清楚某件事情时，你前额皮质的工作记忆有点疯狂吗？当然，一旦你将这个概念分块，即理解并进行实践，你基本上就有了一个光滑的“丝带”，可以在需要时轻松调入工作记忆，从而让其他工作记忆槽位可以处理其他相关的神经块，将它们结合在一起形成更高级的思想。这是一个关键思想。

If you want to see true procedural fluency, that is brilliantly chunked expertise in action, take a look at Mr. Kazuyuki Takayanagi, the president of Soroban Kyoshitsu USA, which is actually located in Japan, as he works with two young children who are learning to add numbers incredibly quickly in their heads using a technique called Flash Anzan It’s almost impossible to believe that anyone could add that fast, much less young children, but add they can. What this means is that the rhythms of quickly practicing addition have formed fundamental neural structures that these children can access rapidly, easily, and largely subconsciously, which means that their conscious working memory can be working on more advanced ideas that build on the simpler ideas of addition. Some children can actually play verbal games while they’re doing Flash Anzan because the verbal processing uses a different part of the brain. I sometimes have students come to me saying they suffer from test anxiety. Test anxiety does exist. I suffer from it myself. But after decades of teaching, I’ve come to realize that those who claim test anxiety often simply haven’t studied well. Of course they feel anxious when they sit down to do a test. It’s just that they haven’t studied the material. Only when the test is put in front of them do they look deeply enough to realize that they didn’t understand it, it’s too late, and they panic. So remember, conceptual understanding is important, but equally important is practice and repetition enhanced by a healthy dose of memorization. I’m Barbara Oakley, happy Mindshift. 如果你想看到真正的程序流畅性，也就是出色的知识分块应用，可以看看高柳和之先生，他是位于日本的美国算盘教室（Soroban Kyoshitsu USA）的校长。他与两个正在使用一种叫做“Flash Anzan”的技术快速心算的孩子们一起工作。几乎令人难以置信的是，居然有人可以加得如此之快，更别提这些年轻的孩子们，但他们确实可以做到。这意味着快速练习加法的节奏形成了这些孩子能够迅速、轻松且主要是潜意识地访问的基本神经结构，这样他们的意识工作记忆可以处理建立在加法基础上的更高级的想法。

一些孩子在进行Flash Anzan时实际上可以玩语言游戏，因为语言处理使用了大脑的不同部分。我有时会有学生来找我，说他们有考试焦虑。考试焦虑确实存在，我自己也有过这种体验。但经过数十年的教学，我逐渐意识到，那些声称有考试焦虑的人，往往只是没有很好地学习材料。坐下来参加考试时，他们当然会感到焦虑。这仅仅是因为他们没有掌握材料。当考试摆在他们面前时，他们才会深入认识到自己没有理解，已经太晚了，于是感到恐慌。

所以，请记住，概念理解很重要，但同样重要的是通过健康的记忆练习和重复来增强学习效果。我是芭芭拉·奥克利，祝你思维转变愉快！

2-7 Bad Grades and Barb’s Hands – The Value of Mental Tricks

So it was at age 26 when I started to try and retrain my brain from being a linguist to becoming more technical. I worked very hard at this, but I couldn’t resist the opportunity to keep having adventures. A couple years into my brain retraining exercise, I had the opportunity to go to the Bering Sea and work as a Russian translator on Soviet trawlers. And then the unexpected opportunity arose for me to work as a radio operator at the South Pole Station in Antarctica. Exciting times, except for one thing. All this meant that I took about a year off from the electrical engineering program I just worked so hard to be accepted into. The semester I finally returned to the university after my adventures, it might be no surprise to learn that I struggled. I’d lost some of my newly acquired fluency with math and equations. After all, I’d been away for a year. When I got to my end of semester grades, I was distraught. In fact, I was so disappointed in myself, that I kept feeling upset and stressed for weeks. Have you ever noticed my hands? They’ve got, let’s say, a kind of interesting twist to them. This is because when I let stressful emotions take over my life, I open myself up to disease. I was only 29 years old at the time, but right in the middle of my stressful reaction to bad grades, I acquired rheumatoid arthritis. Allowing yourself to react inappropriately to stressful events can open the door to serious disease, including not only rheumatoid arthritis, but even cancer. It’s not like it’s just a temporary thing. Obviously these kinds of diseases can affect you for the rest of your life or even shorten your life. Nobel Prize winning psychologist Daniel Kahneman makes a vital point when he observes nothing in life is as important as you think it is, while you’re thinking about it. This is a very useful thought to keep in mind to help put your life into perspective. Unfortunate things happen to everyone. But if you react badly, you can end up making those things even worse. At that time, I just didn’t have the cognitive tools I needed to be able to handle stress better. I didn’t realize that simple mental tricks can be invaluable not only in reducing stress but also overall in helping me to be more effective, productive, and happy in my life and my learning. So what kinds of mental tricks am I talking about? First, let me give you a little background. Let’s say you’re visiting a zoo and you see a snake in a cage. No big deal right. But now let’s imagine that you see that snake outside the cage slithering towards you, very different. You see, the context with which you view something makes an enormous difference. If you learn to put a mental cage, a better frame, around your stressful thoughts it can help you move forward in a positive way. Anyone can learn and develop mental tricks to help them reframe negative thoughts in a more positive way. In the next video, we’ll learn some of the most powerful of these tricks. 在26岁时，我开始尝试将我的大脑从语言学家重新训练为更具技术性的思维。我为此付出了很多努力，但我无法抗拒继续冒险的机会。在我进行大脑重训练的几年来，我有机会去白令海，作为苏联拖网船的俄语翻译工作。随后，我意外地获得了在南极洲南极站担任无线电操作员的机会。那段时间很激动，除了一个问题。这一切意味着我从刚刚努力进入的电气工程项目中休息了一年。当我最终在经历了冒险后返回大学时，可能不出所料，我遭遇了困难。我失去了一些新获得的数学和方程式的流利度。毕竟，我已经离开了一年。当我看到学期末的成绩时，我感到非常沮丧。实际上，我对自己如此失望，以至于连续几周感到不安和压力。

你有没有注意到我的手？它们有点独特的扭曲。这是因为当我让压力情绪占据我的生活时，我就会让自己容易得病。那时我只有29岁，但在我因糟糕的成绩而产生的压力反应中，我得了类风湿性关节炎。让自己对压力事件反应不当可能会导致严重疾病的发生，包括类风湿性关节炎，甚至癌症。这并不是一时的事情。这类疾病显然可能影响你的一生，甚至缩短你的生命。诺贝尔奖获得者心理学家丹尼尔·卡尼曼指出，生活中没有什么事情在你思考时是那么重要的。这是一个非常有用的观点，有助于你更好地看待生活。每个人都会遭遇不幸的事情，但如果你反应不当，就可能使这些事情变得更糟。在那时，我并没有处理压力所需的认知工具。我没有意识到简单的心理技巧不仅可以显著减少压力，还能帮助我在生活和学习中更有效、更高效和更快乐。

那么，我所说的心理技巧是什么呢？首先，让我给你一些背景。假设你在动物园，看到一个蛇在笼子里。这没什么大不了的，对吧？但现在想象一下，你看到那条蛇在笼子外面朝你滑来，那就完全不同了。你看，观看事物的上下文差异很大。如果你学会给自己的压力思维加上一个心理笼子，一个更好的框架，就能帮助你以积极的方式向前推进。任何人都可以学习和发展心理技巧，帮助他们以更积极的方式重新构建消极思维。在下一个视频中，我们将学习这些技巧中一些最强大的方法。

2-8 Learning to Reframe – Put a Label on It!

So what could I have done in reaction to my personal setback with my grades, or with any kind of setback that could have made for a healthier outlook? Putting a label on your feelings, in other words, putting your feelings into a few brief words is one of the most helpful mental tricks you can use when you find yourself being emotionally upset. Applying a label forces you to put your emotional feelings into words. And moving feelings into words helps you shift your thinking from the emotional centers of your brain to the more rational parts of your brain, which automatically begins to tone down your emotions. Fortunately, a field called cognitive therapy has developed a checklist of common emotionally-based distortions of thinking. This checklist provides an automatic set of labels. You can look at these brief descriptive words that I’m going to give you and see which ones fit the emotions you might be feeling when you’re upset. Once you’ve found the words for your feelings, voilà, you’re already beginning to move your thoughts from emotions to more rational cognitions. Not only does this labeling start helping to calm you down, it also helps you to more easily see the distortions In your thinking. Here I’m going to give you some common cognitive distortions based on the list developed by Dr. David Burns and his great book, The New Mood Therapy. It’s worth copying down these distortions and using them as labels to reflect on when something upsets you. Basically, when I felt badly about my grades, I was using every common cognitive distortion in the book. Let’s review them one at a time. 那么，面对我成绩的个人挫折，或者任何类型的挫折，我可以采取什么措施来保持更健康的心态呢？给自己的感受贴上标签，换句话说，就是将自己的感受用简短的词语表达出来，这是当你情绪不安时可以使用的最有帮助的心理技巧之一。给情感贴标签迫使你将情绪感受用语言表达出来，而将情感转化为语言可以帮助你将思维从大脑的情绪中心转移到更理性的部分，这自动会开始减弱你的情绪。

幸运的是，一个叫做认知疗法的领域发展出了一份常见情感基础思维扭曲的检查表。这份检查表提供了一组自动的标签。你可以查看我将要给你的这些简短描述性词语，看看哪些与当你感到不安时可能经历的情感相符。一旦你找到了描述自己感受的词语， voilà，你已经开始将思维从情感转移到更理性的认知上了。这种贴标签的方法不仅有助于让你冷静下来，还帮助你更容易地识别思维中的扭曲。

接下来，我将给你一些基于大卫·伯恩斯博士在他的著作《新情绪疗法》中开发的常见认知扭曲。这些扭曲值得记下来，并在你感到不快时作为反思的标签。基本上，当我对自己的成绩感到不满时，我正好在使用书中列出的每一种常见的认知扭曲。让我们逐一回顾这些扭曲。

First, I was using all or nothing thinking. I felt if I didn’t get good grades, I was a total failure. I mean, really. The reality was that I wasn’t a total failure by any stretch of the imagination. Even if I’d flunked out of the university, I wouldn’t have been a total failure. I was exploding the significance of that semester of poor grades. The reality was that even if I’d flunked out of school, and hadn’t been successful at changing my brain to be able to effectively study math, I likely would’ve found a way to go on and have a successful and happy life. 首先，我使用了全或无思维。我觉得如果我没有取得好成绩，那我就是一个彻底的失败者。实际上，我并不是一个彻底的失败者，完全不应该如此想。即使我退学了，我也不会是一个完全的失败者。我当时夸大了那个学期不佳成绩的重要性。事实上，即使我退学了，且没有成功地改变自己的思维方式来有效学习数学，我仍然可能会找到一种方式继续过上成功和快乐的生活。

And then there’s overgeneralization. I saw one semester’s failure as part of a series of failures in my life. Sure, I’d done badly that semester, but I’ve done badly before. As when I’d been a failure as a signal officer in the military. But previously, I’d also done well at some things, like studying Russian. When I thought I was a failure, I simply wasn’t looking at the bigger picture. I was overgeneralizing in thinking I’d always have bad grades. Remember Nobel Prize winning psychologist, Daniel Kahneman’s point? Nothing in life is as important as you think it is while you’re thinking about it. At that time, I felt like my life was a complete failure. I was obviously wrong. I was also using a mental filter. I was focusing on my one semester’s poor grades and obsessing on them and forgetting about everything else. Here were all these good and beautiful things around me everywhere, and I was ignoring them. I was also discounting the positive. I’d worked hard and previously been able to get good grades. I had a wonderful husband who I’d met at the South Pole station in Antarctica. I had my good health. I was also jumping to conclusions. Somehow, in my mind, I was predicting that things would go badly from then on. The reality was that I didn’t really know what was going to happen from then on out. I was also mind reading. Thinking that others were going to think badly of me. I really had no idea what other people, like my family, would think. I was falling victim to my own emotional reasoning. I assumed that just because I felt negatively about what had happened, that it really was a negative thing. Actually, my feelings had little to do with what was happening in the real world. The whole incident was equivalent to me feeling terrified of the airplane flight, and the flight was actually perfectly fine. I was telling myself I should have done better. Shouldy kind of thinking, these kinds of statements just aren’t helpful. They lead only to guilt, anger, and frustration. I was also using pejoratives of myself. I was telling myself I was stupid, I was an idiot, and that what happened was absolutely terrible. This kind of name calling does no good at all. In fact, it makes you feel bad about yourself and also leaves you feeling angry and frustrated. What happened was unfortunate, but it wasn’t terrible. In fact, getting a few bad grades really wasn’t a big deal at all in the greater scheme of how my life unfolded. Sometimes we take blame and assume responsibility for errors we didn’t make. Or we inappropriately blame others. In my case, I blamed myself for my bad grades. After all, I was to blame for getting away from my studies for a year. But did I really need to drag myself under the bus for having undertaken some great adventures? So we’ve gone over a list of labels you can use to move yourself from an emotionally based framework to a more rational, calmed down part of the brain where you can more carefully analyze and reason away the distortions in your thinking. In the discussion forum, you might want to mention something, anything that’s been bothering you. Then describe what cognitive distortion or distortions you may be using. It might be many of them. Finally, look logically at the distortions you’re using. What is the reality when you put things into a greater life perspective just as I’ve done with that past episode of my own life. Whenever you find yourself growing despondent, sit yourself down, think about what’s really bothering you, go back through those labels, and see how your mind is tricking you. Then develop a rational response. You’ll be surprised at how much better this can make you feel. There’s one more trick you can use to help positively reframe. And that is to find positive ways to think about a negative experience. For example, if you failed at business, think of it as a great learning experience that many ultimately successful entrepreneurs have also had. If you didn’t get the job you wanted, well, that’s leaving you open for a better job ahead. And meanwhile, it’s a great signal for you to upgrade your skills. Did poorly on an exam? Well, maybe that’s a clue to examine your study habits. Your best friend dying of cancer? Well, maybe you want to focus on trying to improve the quality of the life your friend has remaining. 接下来是过度概括。我把一个学期的失败视为我生活中一系列失败的一部分。确实，我那学期表现不好，但我以前也曾表现不佳，比如在军队里当信号军官时的失败。然而，以前我也有一些做得不错的事情，比如学习俄语。当我觉得自己是个失败者时，我实际上没有看到更大的全局。我在过度概括，认为我将永远得不到好成绩。记住诺贝尔奖得主心理学家丹尼尔·卡尼曼的观点吗？在你思考的时候，生活中的事情没有什么比你想的更重要。那时，我觉得我的生活完全失败了，显然我错了。

我还使用了心理过滤。我只关注自己那一个学期的糟糕成绩，并对此感到痴迷，忽视了周围的其他一切。周围有那么多美好的事情，而我却选择忽略它们。我还在贬低积极性。过去我努力工作，能够获得好成绩。我有一个在南极站遇到的很棒的丈夫。我身体健康。我还在草率下结论。在我的脑海中，我预言接下来的事情会变得糟糕。现实是，我并不知道从那时起会发生什么。我还在进行心灵阅读，认为别人会对我有不好的看法。实际上，我对家人等其他人会怎么想根本没有概念。我成为了自己情感推理的受害者。我假设仅仅因为我对所发生的事情感到消极，那确实就是一件负面的事情。实际上，我的感受与现实世界中发生的事情关系不大。这整个事件就像我对飞行感到恐惧，而实际的飞行却完全正常。

我告诉自己应该做得更好。这种“应该”的思维方式并没有帮助，只会导致内疚、愤怒和挫折。我还在自我贬低，告诉自己我很愚蠢，是个傻瓜，所发生的事情简直太糟糕了。这种自我谩骂毫无益处。实际上，它只会让你对自己感到不安，并使你感到愤怒和沮丧。发生的不幸事情确实令人失望，但并不是可怕的。实际上，获得几个不好的成绩在我生活的更大框架中并不算什么。

有时我们会承担不必要的责任，或者不当地指责他人。在我的情况下，我把坏成绩归咎于自己。毕竟，我确实要为自己离开学习一年而负责。但我真的需要因为经历了一些伟大的冒险而惩罚自己吗？

所以，我们讨论了你可以使用的一系列标签，将自己从基于情感的框架转向大脑中更理性、更冷静的部分，在那里你可以更仔细地分析并理清思维中的扭曲。在讨论区，你可以提到一些让你烦恼的事情，然后描述你可能使用的认知扭曲。这可能是许多种。最后，从逻辑上审视你正在使用的扭曲。当你将事情放入更广阔的生活视角时，现实是什么，就像我对自己过去生活的那一集所做的那样。

每当你发现自己变得沮丧时，坐下来，想一想真正困扰你的是什么，回顾这些标签，看看你的思维是如何欺骗你的。然后制定一个理性的回应。你会惊讶于这样做能让你感觉好得多。还有一个技巧可以帮助你积极地重新构建思维，那就是以积极的方式看待负面经历。例如，如果你在商业上失败，可以把它视为许多最终成功的企业家也曾经历的宝贵学习经验。如果你没有得到你想要的工作，那就意味着你为未来更好的工作留出了空间。同时，这是一个很好的信号，提醒你提升自己的技能。如果你在考试中表现不佳，那也许是一个检查你学习习惯的线索。你的好朋友因癌症去世？那么，也许你想关注如何改善你朋友剩余生命的质量。

Positively reframing isn’t just mental trickery. It extinguishes negative emotions that are arising from that fight or flight center of the amygdala. It seems that consciously finding a way to change the meaning of what’s being experienced reduces the flood of stress-related neurotransmitters that are released by the hyper-vigilant amygdala. You might wonder what positive thing could possibly have come from my having rheumatoid arthritis? Simple, if it helps give you a visual reminder you can call to mind to help calm yourself down and reframe in the face of the stress that will inevitably arise in your life. I’ll be back. 积极重新构建思维并不仅仅是心理技巧。它能够消除源自大脑杏仁核的“战斗或逃跑”中心所产生的负面情绪。似乎有意识地找到改变所经历事情意义的方法，可以减少由高度警觉的杏仁核释放的与压力相关的神经递质的涌现。你可能会想，从我得类风湿性关节炎中，可能有什么积极的事情呢？简单来说，如果它能帮助你提供一个视觉提醒，帮助你在生活中不可避免出现压力时冷静下来并进行重新构建，那么它就是有意义的。我会回来。

2-9 Integrate All Your Senses Into Learning – The Pitfalls of “Learning Styles”

There’s a lot of misinformation out there about the concept of learning styles. To help keep you on track with your learning, I’d like to give you some quick insight into what researchers have found and what it means for you. People receive and process new information in different ways. Pretty much all researchers agree with that idea. But what supporters of learning styles theory propose is something more. That people learn best when information is presented in a person’s preferred learning style. Visual learners for example would recall and understand better if they can see the material as opposed to audio learners who would recall and understand the material better, if they can hear the material. But here’s what researcher Beth Rogowsky and her colleges had found when they carefully analyzed some of the most common learning styles. If you take a standardized adult learning style inventory that shows you’re a visual learner, you actually don’t do any better when you’re reading the words, than if you hear the words. Likewise if you test out as an auditory learner, you don’t learn any better when you hear the material as opposed to when you can see it. In other words, there is no statistically significant difference when it comes to the relationship between a learning style preference and instructional method for your ability to comprehend the materials. Not only has research shown then that targeting your best learning style, doesn’t appear to help you learn better, it seems like relying on your preferred style weakens your ability to learn using other senses. For example, if you think you’re an auditory learner and you try to focus on learning by listening, what that means is you’re getting less practice with reading, using your eyes. But being able to read well is an important skill in today’s world. In fact, if you’re an auditory learner, that’s what you think you are, and you catered to your supposed need for auditory materials, then you’re actually undercutting your ability to learn using one of the most common and important ways that most people receive information, that is, using visual means. How are you going to do well on typical standardized test, for example, if you don’t practice the highly visual art of reading. 关于学习风格的概念，有很多误导性的信息。为了帮助你更好地掌握学习，我想给你一些关于研究者发现的快速见解，以及这对你意味着什么。人们以不同的方式接收和处理新信息，几乎所有研究者都同意这一观点。但学习风格理论的支持者提出的观点更进一步。他们认为，当信息以个人偏好的学习风格呈现时，人们学习效果最佳。例如，视觉学习者如果能看到材料，会更好地回忆和理解，而听觉学习者则更好地理解和回忆听到的材料。

然而，研究者贝丝·罗戈斯基及其同事在仔细分析了一些最常见的学习风格后发现，如果你在标准成人学习风格调查中显示自己是视觉学习者，实际上在阅读文字时并不会比听到文字时表现得更好。同样，如果你测试出是听觉学习者，你在听到材料时也并不会比看到材料时学习得更好。换句话说，在学习风格偏好和教学方法之间，与理解材料能力之间的关系没有统计学上的显著差异。

研究表明，针对你最擅长的学习风格并没有提高学习效果，依赖于你的偏好风格反而削弱了你使用其他感官学习的能力。例如，如果你认为自己是听觉学习者，并试图专注于通过听觉学习，这意味着你就会减少用眼睛阅读的练习。但在当今世界，良好的阅读能力是一项重要技能。事实上，如果你是听觉学习者，认为自己是，并且迎合你对听觉材料的所谓需求，那么你实际上是在削弱自己使用大多数人获取信息的最常见和重要的方式之一——视觉方式的学习能力。例如，如果你不练习阅读这种高度视觉化的技能，你如何在典型的标准化考试中表现良好呢？

It seems we often learn best when we can integrate what we’re learning using a lot of our different senses including hearing, seeing and perhaps especially being able to feel with our hands, like what you’re hopefully doing right now, seeing me, listening to what I’m telling you and maybe even taking notes of it with a pen or pencil in your hand. And feeling the paper on your notebook. 我们似乎在学习时，能够整合多种感官——包括听、看，尤其是用手去感受时，效果最好。就像你现在可能正在做的，看到我，听我告诉你的内容，也许还用手中的笔或铅笔做笔记，感受笔记本上的纸张。这种多感官的学习方式能够增强我们的理解和记忆。

Learning styles forms a big industry. Authors and companies make a lot of money from the tests they devise, administer, and teach workshops about. So there’s a big push to the idea that teaching to learning styles is important, even if there’s a lack of scientific evidence for these claims, and even if teaching to learning styles can actually be harmful. So, a word to the wise, whenever you’re learning something, try to take advantage of all of your senses. Don’t characterize yourself as just having one preferred learning style. Instead think of yourself as an all inclusive type learner, you’ll learn so much better as a result. 学习风格形成了一个庞大的产业。作者和公司通过设计、实施测试和教授研讨会赚取了大量利润。因此，有一种强烈的趋势认为，按照学习风格进行教学是重要的，尽管对此的科学证据缺乏，甚至按照学习风格教学可能会产生负面影响。因此，建议你在学习任何东西时，尽量利用所有的感官。不要把自己定义为仅有一种偏好的学习风格。相反，认为自己是一个全面的学习者，这样你将能获得更好的学习效果。

2-10 Can You Try to Learn Too Much?

In this video, we’re going to explore a question that many educators find a little bit uncomfortable. Can you try to learn too much? Ana Belen Sanchez-Prieto, professor of medieval manuscript studies and archive management in Madrid gives interesting insight about this. Ana had her doubts about online education, but when she was given the opportunity to teach a MOOC, she decided to do some exploration to get a better understanding of the online world. Since Ana was going to create an online class, she wanted to try one out herself first. I took the MOOC, Archaeology’s Little Dirty Secrets And I loved it. It gave me a lot of ideas for my own online class. But I also learned that I had a lot to learn about effective teaching, so I enrolled in another MOOC, Foundations of Teaching for Learning. Then I took the complete specialization. Then I took every education-related MOOC I could find. But then, I began to discover that I could take MOOCs on things I wondered about but have never had the chance to learn, such as computers. Dr Chuck’s classes on the Internet and Python were fantastic eye openers. Then I started taking classes on HTML and other tools for web development. Then I started working my way through math with Khan Academy. I’ll be honest, I got carried away. 在这段视频中，我们将探讨一个许多教育工作者觉得有些不舒服的问题：你能否学习过多？马德里中世纪手稿研究与档案管理教授安娜·贝伦·桑切斯-普列托对此提供了有趣的见解。安娜对在线教育持有怀疑态度，但当她获得教授慕课的机会时，她决定进行一些探索，以更好地理解在线学习的世界。由于安娜要创建一个在线课程，她想先尝试一个。

于是，我参加了名为《考古学的小秘密》的慕课，我非常喜欢这个课程。它给了我很多关于自己在线课程的灵感。但我也意识到我在有效教学方面还有很多要学习的，所以我注册了另一个慕课，《学习的基础》。然后我完成了整个专业课程，接着参加了我能找到的所有与教育相关的慕课。

然而，我开始发现我可以参加我感兴趣但从未有机会学习的课程，比如计算机。查克博士关于互联网和Python的课程让我大开眼界。接着，我开始学习HTML和其他网页开发工具。然后，我开始通过可汗学院学习数学。老实说，我有些沉迷于这种学习。

It caused real stress because I also have my own classes. My social life began vanishing. Finally, I have to face it, I was addicted to MOOCs and what is worse? I often wasn’t really learning because I was focused more on finishing and getting the certificate. In the end I realized that many things can be interesting to learn about, but I had to choose. 这导致了真正的压力，因为我还有自己的课程。我的社交生活开始消失。最终，我不得不面对这个事实，我对慕课上瘾了，甚至更糟的是，我常常并没有真正学习，因为我更关注的是完成课程和获得证书。最后，我意识到，虽然许多事情都很有趣，但我必须做出选择。

A few months after her cold turkey withdrawal from MOOCs, Ana went back to MOOCing but this time she took a more balanced approach. She started sitting in on a MOOC on game design so she can apply gaming techniques to improve her classes. She’s planning to repeat the gaming class again before formally enrolling, so she really learns the material. Ana’s objective now is simply to learn but not to be overwhelmed and in the end Ana’s MOOC, Deciphering secrets:The illuminated Manuscripts of Medieval Europe finally launched. 几个月后，在彻底戒掉慕课后，安娜又开始上慕课，但这次她采取了更平衡的方法。她开始旁听一门关于游戏设计的慕课，以便应用游戏技术来改善她的课程。她计划在正式注册之前再次参加游戏课程，以确保自己真正掌握材料。安娜现在的目标很简单，就是学习，而不是感到不堪重负。最终，安娜的慕课《解读秘密：中世纪欧洲的彩绘手稿》成功推出。

But Ana’s path to balance inner life and her learning be a guide for you. Happy balanced mindshift. 但安娜在平衡内心生活与学习的过程中所走的道路可以成为你的指引。祝你拥有愉快而平衡的思维转变！

2-11 Your Social Brain

Who you hang out with strongly influences who you are. You will behave with more decorum in a group of serious scholars than with a group of drinking buddies. A colleague at Oxford University married a Danish woman once, and he told me his relationship with his wife changed once he learned Danish. They fell in love with each other speaking English. He wanted to learn Danish so he could get to know her better. When he spoke to his wife in Danish, he discovered she was a different person, and they fell out of love. Different languages, different personalities. Google once did an in-depth study to find out what factors went into making a successful team. Were the best teams made up of people with similar interests? Did it matter whether everyone was motivated by the same rewards? How often did teammates socialize outside their office? Did they have the same hobbies? Were their educational backgrounds similar? Was it better for all teammates to be outgoing, or for all of them to be shy? They started Project Aristotle to find out, and what they discovered was that none of these factors predicted success. For example, some successful teams had similar backgrounds, but others came from different backgrounds. Finally, they hit on one factor that predicted how well teams innovated. They called the factor “psychological safety”. What was important was that the members of the team felt comfortable taking risks and sometimes failing. This encouraged team members to have interpersonal trust and to mutually respect everybody, feeling comfortable being themselves. The most successful teams had the most empathy. If you want to be successful working together with others, seek out those who are socially sensitive and can empathize with each other. Empathy can be enhanced by chemicals that affect brain chemistry. Ecstasy is a popular psychoactive drug taken at parties to enhance sociality. It produces a sense of well-being and happiness, including feelings of closeness with others, increased emotionality, enhanced sensation, and a sense of inner peace. Ecstasy causes a massive release of serotonin in the brain. Serotonin is one of the major neurochemical messengers found in the brain of every vertebrate, including ours. Neurons in the brain stem that manufacture serotonin project widely, influencing billions of neurons in the cerebral cortex - the most highly evolved part of the human brain. But there is also a downside to taking Ecstasy. Ecstasy releases most of the available serotonin in the brain and you become withdrawn, less social, for weeks that it takes to fully replenish your supply of serotonin. Prozac, a drug that is effective in treating some types of depression, also increases serotonin activity in humans by blocking the re-uptake of serotonin by neurons. Even many who do not suffer from clinical depression find that it lifts their mood, making them feel self-confident and more sociable. In contrast to Ecstasy, however, those who take Prozac only begin to feel better about themselves after many weeks of taking it, and the effects last much longer. Ecstasy, by contrast, alters serotonin levels very rapidly and depletes its stores, whereas Prozac causes a slower and longer term buildup in serotonin activity. Brain serotonin levels depend heavily on the environment. Lack of maternal care in nonhuman primates leads to reduced levels of serotonin, greater aggression, more alcohol consumption, and more anxiety-like behaviors during adolescence. Low levels of serotonin in stressed brains can make for a chemical tripwire for extreme and unpredictable violence. Low serotonin levels also spark a cycle of aggressive behavior and social illiteracy that sets up a child for school failure and peer rejection. Inmates in jail for violent crimes have some of the lowest levels of serotonin activity in society. Your social brain is swimming in a sea of neuromodulators, like serotonin, that affect your temperament. The set points are determined during development, and depend on early experience, but they can be changed by moving to a new environment, where you are surrounded by different people. Choose friends and coworkers who have aspirations that fit into your goals. 你和谁交往会强烈影响你是谁。在一群严肃学者中，你的行为会更加端庄，而在一群喝酒的朋友中，你的行为可能就会随意得多。牛津大学的一位同事曾经娶了一位丹麦女性，他告诉我，当他学会丹麦语后，他和妻子的关系发生了变化。他们最初是用英语相互爱慕的。他想学习丹麦语，以便更好地了解她。当他用丹麦语和妻子交流时，他发现她变成了一个不同的人，他们的爱也随之减退。不同的语言，塑造不同的个性。

谷歌曾进行过一项深入研究，以了解成功团队的组成因素。最佳团队是由兴趣相似的人组成吗？每个人是否被相同的奖励所激励，这重要吗？队员们在办公室外社交的频率有多高？他们有相同的爱好吗？教育背景是否相似？所有队员都是外向型人，还是都是内向型人，哪个更好？他们启动了“项目亚里士多德”来探究，发现这些因素都无法预测成功。例如，一些成功的团队背景相似，而其他团队则来自不同的背景。

最终，他们找到了一个能够预测团队创新能力的因素，他们称之为“心理安全”。重要的是团队成员感到舒适，能够冒险并在某些情况下接受失败。这鼓励了团队成员之间的相互信任和尊重，使大家能够舒适地做自己。最成功的团队拥有最多的同理心。如果你想与他人合作取得成功，就要寻求那些具有社会敏感性、能够相互理解的人。

同理心可以通过影响大脑化学的化学物质得到增强。摇头丸是一种在派对上流行的精神活性药物，用于增强社交性。它产生幸福感，包括与他人亲近的感觉、情感的增强、感觉的提升和内心的宁静。摇头丸会在大脑中大量释放血清素。血清素是每个脊椎动物（包括我们）大脑中发现的主要神经化学信使之一。制造血清素的脑干神经元广泛投射，影响大脑皮层中数十亿个神经元——人类大脑中最高度进化的部分。

但是，服用摇头丸也有其缺点。摇头丸释放了大脑中大部分可用的血清素，使你在几周内变得孤僻、社交能力减退，直到血清素水平完全恢复。百忧解（Prozac）是一种有效治疗某些类型抑郁症的药物，它通过阻止神经元对血清素的再摄取来增加人类的血清素活性。即使许多没有临床抑郁症的人也发现它能够提升他们的情绪，让他们感到自信和更具社交能力。然而，与摇头丸不同，服用百忧解的人通常需要在服用几周后才能感受到自我改善，且效果持续时间更长。相比之下，摇头丸迅速改变血清素水平并耗尽其储备，而百忧解则导致血清素活性的缓慢而长期的增加。

大脑中的血清素水平在很大程度上依赖于环境。在非人类灵长类动物中，缺乏母性关怀会导致血清素水平降低，攻击性增强，酒精消费增加，以及青春期出现更多焦虑样行为。压力较大的大脑中的低血清素水平可能会成为极端和不可预测暴力行为的化学导火索。低血清素水平还会引发攻击性行为和社会无知的循环，这会使孩子在学校失败并被同龄人排斥。因暴力犯罪而入狱的囚犯在社会中通常血清素活性最低。

你的社交大脑浸泡在诸如血清素等神经调节剂的海洋中，这些物质影响着你的气质。设置点是在发展过程中决定的，取决于早期经验，但通过转移到一个新环境中，身边的人群不同，它们是可以改变的。选择那些有抱负并与你的目标相符的朋友和同事。

2-12 Week 2 Wrap Up

We’ve had a lot of fun this week going deeper into what’s needed to learn effectively. We reviewed some useful tricks like the Pomodoro Technique to help you keep your focus on what you’re trying to learn or accomplish. Increasing your expectancy of success, your feelings about the value of the task and removing distractions are also important ways of improving your ability to retain focus. But we also found that, perhaps surprisingly, you don’t always want to keep your focus on your learning. In fact, a valuable part of any learning process involves stepping back after periods of intent focus. Allowing more diffuse mode consolidation to take place involving whatever you’re trying to master. 本周我们深入探讨了有效学习所需的要素，感到非常愉快。我们回顾了一些有用的技巧，例如番茄工作法，这有助于你保持对学习或完成任务的专注。提高成功的期望值、对任务价值的感受，以及消除干扰，也是提高保持专注能力的重要方法。但我们也发现，或许令人惊讶的是，你并不总是需要将注意力集中在学习上。实际上，任何学习过程中的一个宝贵部分就是在专注一段时间后退后一步，让更为广泛的模式巩固得以进行，这涉及到你所尝试掌握的内容。

We can also better prepare our brains for the type of discovery we want to do in our lives by choosing the appropriate form of meditation. Focused attention types of meditation enhances our ability to focus and can calm our brain. While open monitoring types seem to enhance our creative abilities. Gaining expertise at anything doesn’t just involve understanding the concept, it also involves, practice, repetition, and yes, even some memorization. You want to feel so comfortable with key concepts that you don’t have to even think about them, you can just use them. This kind of understanding means building neural chunks. That is, well connected neural patterns that you can draw to mind when you need them, much like computer sub-routines. This approach to learning can lead to extraordinary results. Procrastination can be productive, if you’re using that time to synthesize information you’re gathering or have already gathered. But don’t fool yourself into thinking that procrastination is quite all right when you’re learning or trying to understand something new, especially if it’s difficult. New thinking involves growing new neural connections and that takes time. 我们还可以通过选择合适的冥想形式来更好地为自己生活中的探索做好准备。专注注意力的冥想类型增强我们的专注能力，并能够平静我们的思维，而开放监控类型的冥想似乎增强了我们的创造力。在任何领域获得专业知识不仅仅涉及理解概念，还需要实践、重复，甚至一些记忆。你希望对关键概念感到如此熟悉，以至于无需思考，就能轻松运用。这种理解意味着建立神经块，即能够在需要时提取的良好连接的神经模式，类似于计算机的子例程。这种学习方法可以带来非凡的成果。

如果你利用拖延时间来综合你正在收集或已经收集的信息，那么拖延可以是富有成效的。但不要自欺欺人地认为在学习或尝试理解新事物时，特别是当它很困难时，拖延是完全可以接受的。新的思维涉及到生长新的神经连接，而这需要时间。

We also learned that restricting yourself to one preferred learning style is a bad idea. Try to learn using many approaches. Your eyes, your hearing, your hands, and of course, your imagination through metaphor. It’s also a good idea to use common sense in your learning. Don’t take on too much or it can suck the joy from the experience. A great way to make learning and actually anything you do, more fun, is to hang out or work with the right group of people who will support you in positive ways. Mental tricks can be invaluable in helping us to reframe seemingly bad occurrences so that we can minimize our stress and reduce the bad effects that stress can have not only on our mental health but on our physical health. Putting a label on your feelings is one of the most helpful mental tricks you can use when you find yourself emotionally upset. We learned many of the common ways that our mind can mentally distort the reality of what’s going on. Reframing to put a better light on whatever’s causing you stress in your life isn’t just mental trickery. Reframing extinguishes negative emotions arising from the fight or flight center of the amygdala. That sums things up this week in mindshift. Next week, we’re on to learning and careers. Whatever stage you are in life, whether starting out, mid career, or in retirement, you’ll find there’s a lot there for you. And as you’ll see, sometimes your worst traits can be your best traits. 我们还了解到，局限于一种偏好的学习风格是一个坏主意。尝试使用多种方法进行学习。运用你的视觉、听觉、触觉，当然还有通过隐喻发挥你的想象力。运用常识进行学习也是一个好主意。不要承担过多的任务，否则可能会削弱学习的乐趣。让学习和你所做的任何事情更加有趣的一个好方法是，与那些能够以积极方式支持你的人在一起工作或交往。

心理技巧在帮助我们重新构建看似糟糕的经历方面是非常宝贵的，这样我们就能减轻压力，并减少压力对心理健康和身体健康的负面影响。给情感贴上标签是你在情绪不安时可以使用的最有帮助的心理技巧之一。我们学习了许多思维如何扭曲现实的常见方式。重新构建，把压力源重新审视，以更积极的方式看待生活中的问题，不仅仅是心理技巧。重新构建能够消除来自杏仁核“战斗或逃跑”中心的负面情绪。

本周的内容就总结到这里。下周，我们将讨论学习与职业。无论你处于人生的哪个阶段，无论是刚起步、职业中期，还是退休，你都会发现有很多适合你的内容。而且，正如你将看到的，有时你最糟糕的特质可能反而是你最好的特质。

Optional Bonus Video: Interview with Singapore Entrepreneur Adam Khoo

It’s such pleasure to be here with you, today, Adam. And I have to start by just asking you some questions about the Singapore school system, and also about the education system in general and in Asia. Can you give us a little bit of context about what that system is, and what does it mean if you fall off track early on? Sure, so the education system in Asia, especially Singapore, is extremely competitive because most parents want their children to go to the top universities, and to qualify for top courses like medicine, law, engineering. Because they believe that that’s the ticket to a better life, that’s the ticket to success in life. And so because of the limited places, the truth is less than 10% of every cohort can make it to those courses. So if you don’t get straight As, you don’t stand a chance, so everyone’s really pressured to do well. In fact, in places like India, they compete at a decimal point level. So if you get 99%, it’s not good enough, you have to get 99.9% or 99.8%. And so as a result, parents spend hundreds of dollars, or even thousands of dollars, sending their children to tuition supplementary classes to just give them the competitive edge. And at a very young age of nine years old, in grade three, they’re already streamed, based on their grades for the first three years. So the good students go to the gifted program, the special course, and the average students go to the express course, and the below average will then go to the normal stream, or the normal technical stream. So if you go to a good course, you get more challenging questions, you get more resources. You go to the less able course, again, less resources, less challenging questions. So at a young age, you already start to create that belief in yourself that I’m not as good as someone else, and it’s a pressure to perform to get to a better course. If not, you’re label as you can never make it to a good course. 今天能和你在一起真是太高兴了，亚当。我想先问你一些关于新加坡教育系统以及亚洲教育系统的一般问题。你能给我们提供一些关于这个系统的背景信息吗？如果在早期偏离了轨道，那意味着什么？

当然，亚洲的教育系统，尤其是新加坡，竞争非常激烈，因为大多数父母希望他们的孩子能进入顶尖大学，学习医学、法律、工程等热门专业。他们相信，这些专业是通往更好生活和成功的钥匙。因此，由于名额有限，实际上不到10%的学生能进入这些专业。如果你不能取得全A的成绩，你就没有机会，因此每个人都面临着巨大的压力。事实上，在印度等地方，竞争激烈到小数点的水平。如果你的成绩是99%，那还不够，你必须达到99.9%或99.8%。

因此，父母花费数百甚至上千美元让孩子上补习班，以帮助他们获得竞争优势。而在九岁时，三年级的学生已经根据前三年的成绩进行分流。优秀的学生进入天才班和特别课程，普通学生进入快速课程，低于平均水平的学生则进入普通课程或普通技术课程。进入好的课程意味着你会面临更具挑战性的问题和更多的资源，而较差的课程则相应地资源较少，问题较简单。

因此，在很小的年纪，你就开始在内心建立这样的信念：自己不如其他人，并且面临着必须表现出色以进入更好课程的压力。否则，你就会被贴上“无法进入好课程”的标签。

So this brings us exactly to our next question. You were expelled early on for misbehavior from elementary school, and then you were at the bottom of your class. You ended up what, bottom 10 out of 160 students? Yeah. And that was in secondary school. So at that time, you were convinced you were a complete loser, and that you could never be as good as the other students, and why even try. Yep. So what turned you around? 这正好引出了我们的下一个问题。你在小学时因为不良行为被开除，后来在班级里成绩也很差，最后在160名学生中排名倒数第10对吧？是的，那是在中学时。所以那时候，你坚信自己是个彻底的失败者，认为自己永远也无法比得上其他学生，干脆不如尝试。没错。那么，是什么让你改变了这种看法呢？

Yeah, so it was really out of desperation because my dad tried everything. He scolded me, he nagged at me, he sent me for all this extra tuition, but nothing worked. I know how to study, right? I wouldn’t listen to anyone. In desperation, he sent me to this motivational program for students that was supposed to change mindsets and change our lives around, and it really helped. And the thing that really made an impact on me was, I learned about the power of beliefs, about the beliefs about what I could or could not do about what was possible or what was not possible for me. It changed my beliefs about how I saw myself. because in the past, I saw myself again, like you said, as a loser, right? Because everyone told me that. My teachers would say, why are you so lazy? My father would say, what’s wrong with you? Why you keep forgetting everything? So when I went for this course, it began to get me to change how I saw myself. See, I used to believe that if other people can do something, I can’t do it, because they’re smarter than me, they’re better than me, they’re luckier than me. But when I went through this program, it taught me about the power of positive thinking, that we all have the same potential. As human beings, we’ve got tremendous potential, we just don’t make full use of it, and we are all gifted in our own way. We all have the same potential, if we learn how to unleash that potential, that if someone can do something, so can I. It’s just a question of how, it’s a question of strategy. And the other powerful belief I learned was that for things to change, I had to change. See, previously, the belief was that for things to change, my teacher had to change, the exam had to change, right? So number one was the change of belief. Number two, I learned that the reason I couldn’t remember well, or I could not do well, and studies were stopped because I was stupid or slow, was because I was using an ineffective learning strategy. So I began to learn how to learn at the time. For example, how to read more effectively, how to gather information by finding key words, how to make notes in a way that access my creativity. because I love drawing, I love singing, but I got bored very easily. So I learned how to draw mind maps, where I use pictures, I use colors to make boring subjects come alive. And I learned powerful, mnemonic techniques, how to memorize 30 words, 50 words in sequence by visualizing, associating, using sounds and movement. When I started learning all these things, I got excited because for the first time, I could remember a whole list of words. For the first time, I could remember an entire chapter in just a few minutes, using graphic organizers like mind maps. 是的，这真的源于绝望，因为我父亲尝试了所有办法。他骂我、唠叨我，还让我上了许多补习班，但都没有效果。我知道怎么学习，但我根本不听任何人的话。在绝望中，他把我送到一个旨在改变心态和人生的激励课程，结果真的对我有所帮助。对我影响最大的事情是，我了解到信念的力量，关于我能做什么或不能做什么，以及对我来说什么是可能的，什么又是不可能的。这改变了我对自己的看法，因为过去我把自己看作失败者，就像你说的那样。每个人都告诉我这样。我的老师会说：“你怎么这么懒？”我父亲则问：“你怎么了？为什么总是忘记一切？”

所以，当我参加这个课程时，它开始让我改变对自己的看法。以前，我相信如果其他人能做到的事情，那我就做不到，因为他们比我聪明、比我更优秀、比我更幸运。但当我参加这个课程时，它教会了我积极思维的力量，我们每个人都有相同的潜力。作为人类，我们具备巨大的潜力，只是我们没有充分利用它，而我们每个人都有自己独特的才能。如果我们学会如何释放这种潜力，如果别人能做到的事情，我也能做到。这只是一个如何做到的问题，是一个策略的问题。

另一个我学到的重要信念是，要改变事物，我自己必须先改变。之前我的信念是，要改变事物，老师必须改变，考试必须改变，对吧？所以首先是信念的改变。其次，我了解到我无法很好地记忆或学习不好的原因，并不是因为我笨或反应慢，而是因为我使用了无效的学习策略。因此，我开始学习如何学习。例如，如何更有效地阅读，如何通过寻找关键词来收集信息，如何以便于激发创造力的方式做笔记。因为我喜欢绘画和唱歌，但很容易感到无聊。所以我学会了画思维导图，利用图片和颜色让枯燥的学科变得生动。我还学习了强大的记忆技巧，如何通过视觉化、联想、运用声音和动作来记住30个词、50个词的顺序。

当我开始学习这些东西时，我感到兴奋，因为第一次我能记住整整一系列的单词。第一次，我能够在几分钟内记住整整一章，使用像思维导图这样的图形组织工具。

And the third thing I learned was really about how to dream big, how to set goals. I learned that motivation is motive plus action, that the reason I was not motivated was because I had no motive, I didn’t know why I was studying. See, in the past, my father would say, and what grades are you going to get for exams? And I said I don’t know, just pass. And he said, that’s all? And I said, as long as I don’t feel it’s good enough. And he would look at me and say, Adam, five years from now, where will you be? And I’d say, I’ll be at home. And he’d say, where will you be in life? I’d say, I don’t know, all right? So when you don’t have a goal or a compelling dream, you get lost, you get distracted by everything around you. So I learned from the program that to be motivated, I gotta have a motive, I gotta have a why. I’m not studying for my parents, I’m not studying for my teachers, I’m studying for me. So why should I study, all right? So I begin to learn to set goals about what I wanted to achieve in life. And one of the most powerful things I learned from my teacher at that time was that if you want to be exceptional, you have to set goals that challenge you, that stretch you off your comfort zone. So I set a goal to top my school in one year, to get to Victoria Junior College, which was one of the top junior colleges in Singapore. To get to the National University of Singapore, and to get a business faculty, which everyone thought was impossible from where I was, and to become an entrepreneur and a self-made millionaire. And by setting those goals, I got obsessed, I wrote the goals down on a piece of paper, and every single day I’d look at them, and I would get excited by it. And that’s what drove me to take action, to really apply what I learned, and that’s how everything turned around. 我学到的第三件事就是如何做大梦想，如何设定目标。我了解到，动机就是动机加行动，而我没有动力的原因是因为我没有目标，我不知道自己为什么要学习。过去，我父亲会问：“你这次考试能得什么成绩？”我回答：“我不知道，只要及格就行。”他会说：“就这些？”我说：“只要我觉得不太差就行。”然后他会看着我说：“亚当，五年后你会在哪里？”我回答：“我会在家。”他又问：“你的人生会在哪里？”我说：“我不知道，好吗？”所以，当你没有目标或令人信服的梦想时，你会迷失方向，被周围的一切分散注意力。

我从这个项目中学到，要有动力，我必须有一个动机，必须知道“为什么”。我不是为了我的父母学习，也不是为了我的老师学习，我是为了我自己学习。那么，我为什么要学习呢？于是我开始学习如何设定我想在人生中实现的目标。当时我老师教给我的一个最有力的道理是，如果你想要出众，就必须设定挑战性目标，让自己走出舒适区。

因此，我设定了一个目标：在一年内成为学校的第一名，进入维多利亚初级学院，这是新加坡顶尖的初级学院之一，进入新加坡国立大学，学习商科。每个人都认为这对我来说是不可能的，但我设定了这个目标，并开始执着于它。我把目标写在一张纸上，每天都看一遍，心中充满兴奋。这就是驱动我采取行动、真正应用所学的动力，也是让我一切都发生转变的原因。

So of course, as I started taking action, and for the first time in my life, I started paying attention in class, started making notes and asking questions. And again, did I understand everything that the teacher taught? I didn’t, but when I didn’t understand this time, I would just ask, and ask, and ask until I understood it. And the same thing when I read a chapter of my text book for the first time, I wouldn’t get it because I was a slow learner, but you know what, I kept reading it until I got it. And I would mind map that same chapter one, two, three times until I mastered it, so it was pure hard work. And the results began to show. Within the first year, I was right among the top 20 position in my school. Now, my goal was to top the school, so I didn’t achieve the goal. But I always tell myself that when you have a goal, you don’t always achieve it the first time. But that’s not failure, that’s a learning experience. And even if you don’t achieve the goal, it doesn’t matter because by having a goal, it forces you to put in more effort, and you definitely improve. And so to me, I’ve learned that success is not a destination, it’s a journey. As long as I take one step forward, that’s success to me. So the next year, I worked even harder, and got among the top ten position in school. And for my Cambridge O levels of final year, I topped my school. And it was one of the most powerful experiences of my life. And I then went on to Victoria Junior college where also among the top students for for the Cambridge A levels. And I was going through all this I started a business at the side as well. 所以，当然，当我开始采取行动时，我人生中的第一次开始在课堂上认真听讲，开始做笔记和提问。虽然我并不是每次都能理解老师教的内容，但这次我会不断地问、问、再问，直到我理解为止。同样，当我第一次阅读课本的一个章节时，我可能并不明白，因为我是一个慢学习者，但我会继续阅读，直到我明白为止。我会对同一个章节画思维导图，一次、两次、三次，直到我掌握它，这完全是靠努力工作。结果开始显现。在第一年内，我的成绩已经跻身学校前20名。现在，我的目标是成为学校的第一名，所以我没有实现这个目标。但我总是告诉自己，当你有一个目标时，第一次未能实现并不算失败，而是一种学习经验。即使你没有达到目标也没关系，因为有了目标，它迫使你付出更多努力，你肯定会有所提高。

因此，我明白了，成功不是一个目的地，而是一个旅程。只要我向前迈出一步，这对我来说就是成功。于是第二年，我更加努力，进入了学校的前十名。在我的剑桥O Level最后一年，我成为了学校的第一名。这是我生命中最有力的经历之一。随后，我进入了维多利亚初级学院，在剑桥A Level中也位列前茅。在这一切进行的同时，我还开始了自己的副业。

Because I wanted to be that business man, so again my eventual goals with entrepreneur. So, I thought well why wait? Let’s start something now. And I became a DJ for a mobile disco company where I spun records on weekends and school holidays. I saved up $2000 and at 15-years-old, I started up mobile disco company where I created events or birthday parties and corporate functions, so I was making money while I was studying. And then, continued to junior college. When I went to NUS, my event mobile business kept growing. 因为我想成为一名商人，所以我想，何必要等呢？我们现在就开始吧。我成为了一家流动迪斯科公司的DJ，周末和学校假期时我负责播放音乐。我攒了2000美元，在15岁时成立了自己的流动迪斯科公司，组织活动、生日派对和企业活动，这样我在学习的同时也能赚钱。之后，我继续上了初级学院。进入新加坡国立大学时，我的流动迪斯科业务不断壮大。

And I had a goal to top my entire business school in any way. So, I remember at that time, my father looked at me and said, Adam, how can you top NUS? It’s the best and the brightest in Singapore. And I said but you know Dad, in secondary schools, I topped the school. So, I can do it in the NUS. And he said, in secondary school you were not smart. It’s because all your friends were stupid. So, my dad was one of the most negative people around, but he didn’t mean to be negative, it was just his nature. And I’m the kind of person, the more you say I can’t do something, the more I’m going to prove you wrong. So I said, dad, I’m going to show you, I’m going to beat these people, even thought they are from the top schools and I was not from the top school. And within the first year, I mean I didn’t top my faculty, right? I didn’t, again, I didn’t achieve that goal, all right? But I was already among the top 1% of students at NUS. As a pioneer in the NUS Talent Development program, which is now known as a scholar’s program. And to get in you have to be the top 1% of economic achievers in the US. And I was on the dean’s list every single year and finished my four years honors degree in three years. And during that time, I was very passionate to share my story. So I went around to secondary schools, primary schools, to teach the kids about how I turned around from one of the bottom schools to topping the University of Singapore. And that’s when I wrote my book, I’m Gifted So Are You, at 24 in my third year of university. And that’s how it became a best-seller and I got pretty well known in Singapore. 我有一个目标，就是在商学院里名列前茅。所以，我记得那时我父亲看着我说：“亚当，你怎么可能在新加坡国立大学（NUS）出类拔萃？那里都是新加坡最优秀的人。”我说：“爸爸，你知道吗，在中学时我就是学校的第一名，所以我也可以在NUS做到。”他却说：“在中学时你并不聪明，都是因为你的朋友们太笨。”所以，我的父亲是个非常消极的人，但他并不是故意的，这就是他的本性。而我则是那种，越是说我做不到，我就越想证明你错了的人。

于是我对他说：“爸爸，我要让你看看，我会打败那些人，即使他们来自顶尖学校，而我并不是。”在第一年，我并没有在我的专业中名列第一，确实没有实现那个目标。但是我已经在新加坡国立大学的学生中名列前1%。作为NUS人才发展计划的先驱，那个计划现在称为学者计划，想要加入必须是经济学成就的前1%。而且我每年都在院长名单上，并且在三年内完成了四年的荣誉学位。

在这段时间里，我非常热衷于分享我的故事。因此，我去了中学、小学，教孩子们如何从底层逆袭到新加坡大学的顶尖学生。正是在那个时候，我在24岁时写了我的书《我是天才，你也是》，这是我在大学第三年写的。这本书成为了畅销书，我在新加坡变得相当有名。

Well, ok so now we’ve talked a lot about what happened in your school journey but let’s go beyond platitudes and just go straight to what goes on in real everyday life for somebody in their 30s or 40s and what practical advice would you have for a person who’s in mid-career. Who feels trapped in their job. They want to change maybe, and they’re not sure about how to go about doing it. How could you take some of those ideas that you used to turn yourself around when you were young, can you use some of these same approaches when you’re mid-career? Sure. So the principes apply whether you’re in school or in a career. But wherever you are in life, you want a better life. You want to create a change. And again, the first principle is for the things to change, you have to change. So the first thing is to change your thoughts to look at problems as opportunities. To change your beliefs about what you are capable of that just because you are educated as an engineer, doesn’t mean you must be an engineer for the rest of your life. You can be something else. In the old days it was one career for life. But the average person now in the 21st century global economy goes through three to four career changes in their life. Because we know that jobs that exist today, in ten years may no longer exist, they’ll be outsourced or evolved. So, we’ve gotta have the mindset to create a shift. Beyond what we studied in school. That’s number one. Number two is to change our capabilities. And we do that by constant and never-ending improvement. Taking online courses, like learning how to learn, taking life training program where we learn new skills beyond our vocational technical skills. Portable skills like communication skills that can be applied anywhere. 好的，我们已经谈了很多关于你在学校经历的事情，但让我们超越空话，直接谈谈在30多岁或40多岁的人在现实生活中面临的情况，以及你对那些在职业中感到受困、想要改变但不知如何下手的人的实用建议。你如何运用那些年轻时帮助你逆袭的理念，在职业中期时也能使用这些相同的方法呢？

当然，这些原则适用于无论你是在学校还是在职业生涯的任何阶段。不论你处于人生的哪个阶段，如果你想要更好的生活，想要创造变化，首先要明白一个原则：事情要改变，你必须改变。因此，第一步是改变你的思维，将问题视为机会。改变你对自己能力的信念：仅仅因为你受过工程师的教育，并不意味着你必须终生做工程师。你可以成为其他职业的人。过去，很多人只是一辈子从事一份职业。但在21世纪的全球经济中，普通人一生中通常会经历三到四次职业变化。因为我们知道，今天存在的工作在十年后可能就不再存在，它们可能会外包或演变。因此，我们必须具备创造转变的心态，超越我们在学校所学的知识。这是第一点。

第二点是改变我们的能力。这可以通过持续不断的自我提升来实现。参加在线课程，比如学习如何学习，参加生活技能培训，学习超出职业技术技能的新技能。掌握可转移的技能，例如沟通技巧，这些技能可以应用到任何地方。

Creativity skills, problem-solving skills, management skills and that thing, of course, would be to change by taking action, by taking a first step, by networking and that’s how you will see the dots slowly being connected and find new ways to find new careers that you’re more passionate about. 创造力技能、解决问题的技能、管理技能等等，当然，要实现这些变化，就必须采取行动，迈出第一步，进行网络交流。通过这些方式，你会慢慢看到各个点之间的联系，找到更让你充满热情的新职业道路。

So this leads right into our next question which is what do you do to help keep yourself motivated? What would you recommend to adults and older people who haven’t experienced your kind of success to help them keep a positive attitude? 这就引出了下一个问题：你通常怎么做来保持自己的积极性？你会推荐给那些没有经历过你那种成功的成年人和年长者什么方法，以帮助他们保持积极的态度？

So let me just say, first of all, I don’t wake everyday going yes. People think that successful people are motivated every single morning when they wake up, nothing could be further from truth. There are days I wake up, I don’t feel I’m waking at all, all right. So, we all get lazy, and if you feel lazy at times, that’s natural. So, motivation is like bathing. You can’t bathe once and be clean for the rest of your life. You have to bathe every single day. So similarly, you have to motivate yourself every single day when you don’t feel motivated. So the way I motivate myself is number one, when I wake up in the morning, I’ve got a ritual of reading my goals. What are my goals today? What are my goals five years from now? And as I read my goals, I get excited. And that frames my mind for the rest of the day. So, I know that what I’m doing now is moving towards something that is really important in the future. I also like to fantasize a lot. Yeah, right. So, besides reading my goals, I would then visualize myself achieving those goals. Visualize the impact it makes on my family. All right, the people I love, and the world. And how I can change the world in my small, little way. And when I visualize that trend, imagination, it excites me a lot. I also talk about my goals a lot. So whenever I meet people, I tell them, you know what? My new book’s coming out. You know what? I’m going to change my career, for example. Because when I tell people that, it puts me on the line. And we got no choice but to find a way to make it happen. 所以，让我先说，我并不是每天早上醒来就充满动力。人们认为成功的人每天醒来都充满动力，这完全不是事实。有时候我早上醒来时甚至觉得自己没有醒来。所以，我们都会懒惰，如果你感到懒惰，那是很正常的。因此，动力就像洗澡一样。你不能只洗一次澡就保持干净一辈子。你必须每天都洗澡。同样地，当你没有动力时，你也必须每天激励自己。

我激励自己的方式有几个步骤。第一，当我早上醒来时，我会有一个阅读目标的仪式。我会问自己，今天的目标是什么？五年后的目标是什么？当我阅读我的目标时，我会感到兴奋。这为我接下来的一天设定了基调。我知道我现在所做的事情是在朝着一个对未来非常重要的目标前进。

我还喜欢进行大量的幻想。除了阅读目标之外，我还会想象自己实现这些目标的情景，想象这些目标对我的家人、我爱的人以及整个世界的影响，以及我如何以我微小的方式改变世界。当我进行这样的视觉化时，我会感到非常兴奋。

此外，我也会经常谈论我的目标。每当我遇到人时，我会告诉他们，我的新书快要出版了，我要改变我的职业等等。因为当我告诉别人这些时，它就把我推到了一个必须找到方法去实现这些目标的境地。

And when I go through problems, when things don’t go the way I want, which is every day, all right, I’ve learned to reframe it. So, I’ve learned to reframe problems and the opportunities that matter what happens, always believe that things happen for a reason. There’s something you can learn from there. So for example, if I lose a business deal, instead of saying, why did this happen to me? What am I so stupid? Why so unlucky? Ask what can I learn from this? And how can this lead to a breakthrough to get even bigger in the future? And that keeps me motivated. 当我遇到问题时，事情总是不会按照我想要的方式发展，我每天都会面临这种情况。我学会了重新框架这些问题。我学会了将问题重新定义为机会，无论发生什么事，我始终相信事情发生是有原因的，总是可以从中学习到一些东西。

例如，如果我失去了一个商业交易，我不会问“为什么会发生这样的事？我怎么会这么愚蠢？为什么这么不幸？”而是问“我能从中学到什么？这如何能成为一个突破，让我在未来更进一步？”这样的思维方式使我保持了动力。

So sometimes, as you mentioned, you’re not motivated and in fact sometimes you have some bad characteristics. And you’ve had bad characteristic through your life, so can you tell me a little bit about how bad characteristics might actually sometimes be good characteristics. And how might some people in general use their bad characteristics in a way that helps them? Okay, so I believe there’s no such thing as a bad characteristic or good characteristic. At least, no matter how bad a characteristic is in a certain context, when used appropriately, in a different context, can be an asset. So for example, again, one of my bad traits is I’m really stubborn. I’m a nonconformist, when everyone says this, I’ll say, why can’t we do something else? And it irritates the heck out of my teachers and my parents in the past. But I’ve learned to use that to my advantage. So again, when people told me in secondary school that you can’t make it to junior college. You can’t make it to university. That really motivates me to prove them wrong. And so that’s how I’ve used it to my advantage. Another bad trait I would say, bad trait is that I’m slow learner. When I was young my friends could read a chapter of additional mathematics, calculus, and understand it the first time. Teacher could explain it the first time, they got it. I didn’t get it. I had to read that same page three or four times before I got it. Teacher had to explain it a few times before I got it. 所以，正如你提到的，有时你并没有动力，事实上，有时你有一些不好的特质，而你在生活中也经历过这些不好的特质。那么你能告诉我一下，如何将不好的特质有时转变为好的特质？一般来说，人们如何利用他们的不良特质来帮助自己？

好的，我认为没有所谓的坏特质或好特质。至少，无论某种特质在特定的情况下有多么糟糕，如果在不同的背景下适当地使用，它都可以成为一种资产。例如，我的一个坏习惯就是我非常固执。当每个人都说“这样做不行”的时候，我会问，“为什么我们不能尝试其他方式？”这常常让我的老师和父母感到非常恼火。但我学会了将这一点转化为自己的优势。因此，当人们在中学时告诉我，你无法进入初级学院，无法上大学时，这真的激励我去证明他们是错的。这就是我如何利用我的固执。

另一个我认为是坏习惯的特质是我学习得很慢。当我年轻的时候，我的朋友可以在第一次阅读附加数学、微积分的章节时就理解它。老师第一次讲解时，他们就懂了。而我没有。我必须阅读同一页三到四次，才能理解。老师必须多解释几次，我才能明白。

And now I look back, that’s a great asset, because now as a teacher myself, I’m now able to understand how slow learners like me process. And I’m able to take something which is complicated and make it really simple, so that anyone can learn. So again that has, I’ve used that to my advantage as well. So everything which is a liability can be looked at as an asset. 而现在回头看，这其实是一个很好的资产，因为现在作为一名老师，我能够理解像我这样的慢学习者是如何处理信息的。我能够将复杂的知识变得简单，让任何人都能学习。因此，我也将这一点转化为我的优势。所以，任何被视为负担的特质都可以被看作是资产。

We share so much in common, because sometimes I think my best trait as a teacher is that it’s hard for me to understand things, and so I do find that once I understand them, I can only understand it if it’s made simple. But once I do make it simple, it’s much easier to explain to other people. If I was smarter, in some sense, I couldn’t be as effective a teacher. Absolutely. So, what advice do you have for someone who feels that their job skills are becoming obsolete? Which is a very common thing- Sure. To happen today. What can people do to be more resilient in their careers? So the only way to create resilience to protect your career, is to ensure that you make yourself obsolete before someone makes you obsolete, all right. And the only way to do that, again, is through constant and never-ending improvement. And the first thing is an attitude, to ask yourself if what I’m doing now is the same thing I’m doing a year ago, something’s wrong. It’s gotta be better, it’s gotta change. 所以，唯一创造韧性以保护你的职业的方法，就是在别人让你过时之前，先让自己变得过时。只有通过不断地、永不停息地改进，你才能做到这一点。首先，你需要有一个正确的心态，问自己：我现在所做的事情是否和一年前做的一样？如果是，那就有问题了。你必须在某些方面变得更好，必须有所改变。

And always ask yourself, how can I do something better than I did in the past. And I’ve always done that my life. So I love learning, and I’ve always been a lifelong learner. So I go online and I take courses all the time relating to my field or even outside of my field. And that allows me to have the breadth of knowledge and expertise to be able to do anything. So, if my business, if I knock on wood, were to be obsolete tomorrow, I can start a new business doing something else, adding value to the world with the portable skills I’ve created. 总是问问自己，如何能比过去做得更好。我一生中一直都是这样做的。我热爱学习，并且一直是一个终身学习者。因此，我会在线上不断参加与我所在领域相关或甚至是与我领域无关的课程。这让我拥有广泛的知识和专业技能，能够做任何事情。所以，如果我的生意，敲敲木头，明天变得过时，我可以开始一项新的业务，做其他事情，利用我所掌握的可转移技能为世界创造价值。

So, I know that luck plays a role in success in life. How can someone encourage luck? Okay. If you hear a lot of people speak, they say I got lucky, and I got lucky and I got lucky. And I believe that luck can be created. To me, that’s an equation, luck equals to opportunity plus preparation plus action. So the first thing is you need opportunities. So do lucky people have more opportunities than unlucky people? Yes. And the reason is because see, opportunities never look like opportunities. Opportunities always come disguised as problems. And we all have problems. So, in other words, we all have opportunities disguised. But it takes a lucky person to see the opportunity disguised as a problem. 我知道运气在生活中的成功中起着重要作用。人们如何能鼓励运气呢？好吧。如果你听很多人说，他们会说我很幸运，我很幸运，我很幸运。我相信运气是可以创造的。对我来说，这是一种公式：运气=机会+准备+行动。因此，首先你需要机会。那么，幸运的人是否比不幸的人拥有更多机会呢？是的。原因在于，机会从来不看起来像机会。机会总是伪装成问题。我们都有问题。换句话说，我们都有伪装的机会。但只有幸运的人才能看到伪装成问题的机会。

And that can be learned. That’s a shift of your paradigm. That’s a shift of your mindset. So, for example, when I was young, again, my problem was that I was in a lousy class. I was a lousy student. And I always asked myself, why did this happen to me? Why can’t I be a smart student? But at one stage I then said, hey, that problem is an opportunity. Because now I can write a book to share with people how a dumb person like me could top the university, and that’s how it gave birth to the book I’m Gifted, So Are You. See, if I was smart all the way, I couldn’t write that book. I’m Gifted So Are You. There’s no credibility give it back to you, right? So that was an opportunity. The second thing was, I was prepared. In other words, you got to have, you’ve got to be prepared to take advantage of the opportunities. So, if I was not prepared with the ability to write that book, if I was not prepared with the skills on how to promote and to sell that book, it would not have been a successful book. So always ensure you upgrade your skills so you have the internal resources, the creativity, the communication skills, the management skills to take advantage of the opportunities when you see them. And the third thing is the ability to get yourself to take that first step, to take action. because many people I know see the opportunity, they say I know what to do, I know how to do it, I never did it. Because they suffer from paralysis of analysis. What if I fail? People always ask, what if I fail? I look at them and ask them, what if you succeed? 这可以被学习。这是一个思维方式的转变，是范式的转变。例如，当我年轻的时候，我的问题是我在一个差的班级里，我是一个糟糕的学生。我总是问自己，为什么会发生这种事？我为什么不能成为一个聪明的学生？但在某个阶段，我说，嘿，那问题就是一个机会。因为现在我可以写一本书，分享一个像我这样笨的人如何在大学中获得第一名的故事，这就是我写下《我有天赋，你也有》这本书的起源。你看，如果我一直都很聪明，我就无法写那本书《我有天赋，你也有》。没有信誉可言，对吧？所以那是一个机会。第二点是，我已经做好了准备。换句话说，你必须准备好去利用机会。因此，如果我没有准备好写那本书的能力，如果我没有准备好推广和销售那本书的技能，那它就不会成为一本成功的书。因此，要始终确保你提升自己的技能，这样当你看到机会时，你就有内部资源、创造力、沟通技能和管理技能去利用它们。第三点是你必须能够迈出第一步，采取行动。因为我认识的很多人看到机会时，会说我知道该怎么做，我知道如何去做，但我从未去做。因为他们遭受分析麻痹的困扰。人们总是问，如果我失败了呢？我看着他们问，假如你成功呢？

Think about that, right? To me, when you take action, you always get results. You either get results you want or results you don’t want, but you always get results. And if you take action and you get results you don’t want, at least you learned something from it. You’re better than someone else who talked and talked and thought and thought and thought but didn’t do anything at all. So just take action, because you can’t fail unless you don’t learn something from it. Adam, I can’t thank you enough for this great interview, and this is terrific. It’s been a pleasure. Thank you so much. 考虑一下，对吧？对我来说，当你采取行动时，你总会得到结果。你要么得到你想要的结果，要么得到你不想要的结果，但你总会得到结果。如果你采取行动并得到不想要的结果，至少你从中学到了什么。你比那些只是谈论、思考却什么也不做的人要好得多。因此，只需采取行动，因为除非你从中学到东西，否则你就不会失败。亚当，非常感谢你这次精彩的访谈，真是太棒了。非常高兴能与你交流。谢谢你！

Taking this list and putting it in a familiar place like your apartment or your house, your workplace, anything you know really well that you can navigate in your mind’s eye.
